content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Tick all the cases for a good clash of code in my opinion.

"shortest possible distance to *any* of the three corners" does not sound like an accurate definition.  

Would it be more accurate to say that when you sum the distance of the midpoint to the corners it is the minimum possible value?
Great challenge but reverse would be very difficult

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice challenge! However, the name of this point is not `midpoint`, is `centroid`. The reason why this is important is that when it comes to triangles there are a lot of different points inside of them (i.e.: circumcenter, orthocenter, and more). So, in case people want to do more research about this topic, using the correct name might be important.

I like it and gave it an upvote.... but just wanted to comment that this seems a bit more like a math problem than a coding problem.

I peeked at the solution to see how you solved it.  If I know the formula, it is easy to code.  If I don't know the formula, it's impossible to code.

Perhaps you should consider including info about the formula, so it becomes more of a coding problem.

Input section
* Please mention "space-separated".
* Please add line numbers (e.g. <<Line 1:>>) for all inputs (A, B, C).

Output section
* "two digits" should be changed to "two decimal places". (I mean, 588.00 contains 5 digits...?)
Reference: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rounding
* Please mention "space-separated".

Thanks.

Everything is clear to me in the statement, and I think it would make a good CoC.

Not sure if the following remark is relevant, but you could avoid creating lists in the solution you propose:
xs = 0
ys = 0
...
xs += x
ys += y
...
print(f"{xs/3...

Thanks for the feedback. 
You are right - I did consider it.
I wanted to provide as straightforward and easy-to-understand solutions as possible - without giving away partly the shortest solution.
Reading just the last line as pseudo-code and the math should be pretty straightforward.
> print(f"{sum(xs)/3:.2f} {sum(ys)/3:.2f}")
Hopefully making the code even more clear to people from other languages.
I consider it, again.

See your point - this seems a bit more like a math problem than a coding one.
But I'm not sure that I find that a problem as I find the coding challenge in translating the problem from the well-known trigonometric solution to the coordinate system solution - that is remarkably simple.
However, I add some of the maths to the description - and hope this is more of a helping hand to most and not a distraction.
That is a fair point - thanks. I updated the 'The math' section to include this.
Recognized - I remove the reverse challenge.

That is a fair point.
I will try to add that to the math section.
I think you should still drop "any of" in the description.  "any of" means that the user can choose just one.
Again a fair point - I try to improve the description.
